title: 114_hr4370
content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may adjust the FMAP for affected jurisdictions equivalent to Compact migrant expenditures. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will increase the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on estimated Compact migrant expenditures submitted by the chief executive official. The Secretary of the Interior will review and adjust the estimation before submitting it to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will estimate the increase in FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on Compact migrant expenditures submitted by the chief executive official. The Secretary of the Interior will review and adjust the estimation before final submission. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates the increase in FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on Compact migrant expenditures submitted by the chief executive official. The increase in FMAP cannot exceed certain limitations under the Social Security Act, and notification of the increase must be provided 30 days before the quarter begins. Reconciling and payment adjustments are required for each quarter with an FMAP increase. The chief executive official of an affected jurisdiction must submit an accounting of compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior for each quarter with an FMAP increase. The Secretary of the Interior reviews the accounting for accuracy and submits a final accounting to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services makes any necessary adjustments to the accounting. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews the compact migrant expenditures submitted by affected jurisdictions for accuracy and makes adjustments to the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage (FMAP) for future quarters accordingly. The Secretary of Health and Human Services adjusts the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on compact migrant expenditures, ensuring it does not exceed 100 percent. This section does not consider compact migrant expenditures as medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The term "affected jurisdiction" is defined in the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003. The term "compact migrant expenditures" refers to non-Federal funds spent by affected jurisdictions on healthcare for qualified nonimmigrants, as defined in the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003. This includes payments to healthcare providers for services provided to qualified nonimmigrants. The term "compact migrant expenditures" includes payments made by affected jurisdictions to healthcare providers for services provided to qualified nonimmigrants, as defined in the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003. It also refers to the Federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP) as defined in the Social Security Act. Additionally, a conforming amendment to the Social Security Act is made regarding the Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS FOR ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include educating alien children from the Freely Associated States and providing payments for eligible federally connected children who are citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 include providing additional funding for eligible federally connected children who are citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. This includes multiplying the number of children from these countries by a factor of 1.25 and authorizing $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2017 and each succeeding fiscal year for additional payments. Preference for US citizens or nationals in housing financial assistance within Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Independent assessment of the strategic importance of the relationship between the US and the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State aims to partner with an eligible organization for an independent assessment of the strategic significance of the US relationship with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. This assessment will cover the relationships in the Asia-Pacific region, the administration of Compacts of Free Association, and US financial support to Palau. The eligible organization will assess the Compact of Free Association between the United States and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, provide recommendations for improvements, renewal, and future administration of the Compacts, and address any other relevant matters. A report must be submitted to the Secretary of State within one year of the Act's enactment. The eligible organization entering into an agreement under this Act must submit a report to the Secretary of State, including the required assessment, necessary matters, and any additional information deemed appropriate. The report should be in unclassified form but may have a classified annex if needed. The organization can obtain official data from any US department or agency to fulfill the requirements of the agreement. Upon request, the department or agency head must provide the necessary information to the organization.
